review.title: Blind score normalization method for PLDA based speaker recognition
review.abstract: Probabilistic Linear Discriminant Analysis (PLDA) has become state-of-the-art method for modeling $i$-vector space in speaker recognition task. However the performance degradation is observed if enrollment data size differs from one speaker to another. This paper presents a solution to such problem by introducing new PLDA scoring normalization technique. Normalization parameters are derived in a blind way, so that, unlike traditional \textit{ZT-norm}, no extra development data is required. Moreover, proposed method has shown to be optimal in terms of detection cost function. The experiments conducted on NIST SRE 2014 database demonstrate an improved accuracy in a mixed enrollment number condition.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: A study of the automatic verification process for loudspeakers consists in estimating the probability of two statements belonging to the same loudspeaker. Typically, one statement is taken from a group of target speakers, another is an unknown test expression. Decision is made by comparing the verification process with a threshold. The combination of i-vector and probabilistic linear discrimination analysis (PLDA) is a state-of-the-art method for detecting loudspeakers that makes it possible to obtain this evaluation. The i-vector approach is based on the total variability model [1], which represents loudspeaker data in low-dimensional space. PLDA [2] treats the influence of channel variability in i-vector space [3] and also allows the calculation of the log likelihood ratio (LLR) score between target and non-target variability hypothesis. There are two simultaneous hypotheses that make PLDA dependent on the number of probable influencers, whereby there are different influencers available in the score.

sections.heading: 3. Speaker dependent distribution of PLDA scores
sections.text: In this section we derive specific parameters for score distributions of the target and non-target hypotheses. First, we describe the standard PLDA model and then present the score result in multiple use cases. sections.heading: 4.1. Data set and PLDA parameters estimation
sections.text: The dataset consists of a labeled development set (devset), a labeled model set (modelset) with 5 i-vectors per model, and an unlabeled test set (testset). Since labels for the devset were not available during the challenge, the best results were obtained from methods that made it possible to cluster the devset and then apply PLDA [12, 13]. The original devset labels were used in the presented experiments. In our experiments, the datasets were first pre-processed. sections.heading: 4.2. Results
sections.text: The experiments were carried out with different i-vectors per loudspeaker. modelset contains speakers with 5 i-vectors per loudspeaker. we compare the general PLDA evaluation with the proposed normalized evaluation (2) on the following login sets. First, 5 sets of L = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} i-vectors per speaker are configured using the model. This set consists of model set speakers with reduced number of participants and contains 94 speakers with 1 i-vectors per speaker, 93 speakers with 2 i-vectors per speaker, 194 speakers with 3 i-vectors per speaker, 189 speakers with 4 i-vectors per speaker, 113 speakers with 5 i-vectors per speaker.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and Further Work
sections.text: The most important contribution to the existing normalization methods is that this technique does not require any additional development data and is based only on the properties of the PLDA model, which ensures more stable verification values with almost no additional computational costs. Experiments conducted on the NIST SRE 2014 database show that the minimum DCF value in the mixed enrollment condition decreases. In further work, the problem of the non-Gaussian distribution of PLDA values can be considered, which can lead to a more accurate estimate of the specific threshold of the speaker.
